author: HCAndersen
text: ONE would have thought that something important was going on in the duck-pond, but it was nothing after all.

author: HCAndersen
text: All the ducks lying quietly on the water or standing on their heads in it- for they could do that- at once swarm to the sides; the traces of their feet were seen in the wet earth, and their cackling was heard far and wide.

author: HCAndersen
text: The water, which a few moments before had been as clear and smooth as a mirror, became very troubled.

author: HCAndersen
text: Before, every tree, every neighbouring bush, the old farmhouse with the holes in the roof and the swallows' nest, and especially the great rose-bush full of flowers, had been reflected in it.

author: HCAndersen
text: The rose-bush covered the wall and hung out over the water, in which everything was seen as if in a picture, except that it all stood on its head; but when the water was troubled everything got mixed up, and the picture was gone.

author: HCAndersen
text: Two feathers which the fluttering ducks had lost floated up and down; suddenly they took a rush as if the wind were coming, but as it did not come they had to lie still, and the water once more became quiet and smooth.

author: HCAndersen
text: The roses were again reflected; they were very beautiful, but they did not know it, for no one had told them.

author: HCAndersen
text: The sun shone among the delicate leaves; everything breathed forth the loveliest fragrance, and all felt as we do when we are filled with joy at the thought of our happiness.

author: HCAndersen
text: "How beautiful existence is!" said each rose.

author: HCAndersen
text: "The only thing that I wish for is to be able to kiss the sun, because it is so warm and bright.

author: HCAndersen
text: I should also like to kiss those roses down in the water, which are so much like us, and the pretty little birds down in the nest.

author: HCAndersen
text: There are some up above too; they put out their heads and pipe softly; they have no feathers like their father and mother.

author: HCAndersen
text: We have good neighbours, both below and above.

author: HCAndersen
text: How beautiful existence is!"

author: HCAndersen
text: The young ones above and below- those below were really only shadows in the water- were sparrows; their parents were sparrows too, and had taken possession of the empty swallows' nest of last year, and now lived in it as if it were their own property.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Are those the duck's children swimming here?" asked the young sparrows when they saw the feathers on the water.

author: HCAndersen
text: "If you must ask questions, ask sensible ones," said their mother.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Don't you see that they are feathers, such as I wear and you will wear too?

author: HCAndersen
text: But ours are finer.

author: HCAndersen
text: Still, I should like to have them up in the nest, for they keep one warm.

author: HCAndersen
text: I am very curious to know what the ducks were so startled about; not about us, certainly, although I did say 'peep' to you pretty loudly.

author: HCAndersen
text: The thick-headed roses ought to know why, but they know nothing at all; they only look at themselves and smell.

author: HCAndersen
text: I am heartily tired of such neighbours."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Listen to the dear little birds up there," said the roses; "they begin to want to sing too, but are not able to manage it yet.

author: HCAndersen
text: But it will soon come.

author: HCAndersen
text: What a pleasure that must be!

author: HCAndersen
text: It is fine to have such cheerful neighbours."

author: HCAndersen
text: Suddenly two horses came galloping up to be watered.

author: HCAndersen
text: A peasant boy rode on one, and he had taken off all his clothes except his large broad black hat.

author: HCAndersen
text: The boy whistled like a bird, and rode into the pond where it was deepest, and as he passed the rose-bush he plucked a rose and stuck it in his hat.

author: HCAndersen
text: Now he looked dressed, and rode on.

author: HCAndersen
text: The other roses looked after their sister, and asked each other, "Where can she be going to?"

author: HCAndersen
text: But none of them knew.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I should like to go out into the world for once," said one; "but here at home among our green leaves it is beautiful too.

author: HCAndersen
text: The whole day long the sun shines bright and warm, and in the night the sky shines more beautifully still; we can see that through all the little holes in it."

author: HCAndersen
text: They meant the stars, but they knew no better.

author: HCAndersen
text: "We make it lively about the house," said the sparrow-mother; "and people say that a swallows' nest brings luck; so they are glad of us.

author: HCAndersen
text: But such neighbours as ours!

author: HCAndersen

author: HCAndersen
text: I daresay it will be taken away; then we shall, perhaps, have some corn growing here.

author: HCAndersen
text: The roses are good for nothing but to be looked at and to be smelt, or at most to be stuck in a hat.

author: HCAndersen
text: Every year, as I have been told by my mother, they fall off.

author: HCAndersen
text: The farmer's wife preserves them and strews salt among them; then they get a French name which I neither can pronounce nor care to, and are put into the fire to make a nice smell.

author: HCAndersen
text: You see, that's their life; they exist only for the eye and the nose.

author: HCAndersen
text: Now you know."

author: HCAndersen
text: In the evening, when the gnats were playing about in the warm air and in the red clouds, the nightingale came and sang to the roses that the beautiful was like sunshine to the world, and that the beautiful lived for ever.

author: HCAndersen
text: The roses thought that the nightingale was singing about itself, and that one might easily have believed; they had no idea that the song was about them.

author: HCAndersen
text: But they were very pleased with it, and wondered whether all the little sparrows could become nightingales.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I understand the song of that bird very well," said the young sparrows.

author: HCAndersen
text: "There was only one word that was not clear to me.

author: HCAndersen
text: What does 'the beautiful' mean?"

author: HCAndersen
text: "Nothing at all," answered their mother; "that's only something external.

author: HCAndersen
text: Up at the Hall, where the pigeons have their own house, and corn and peas are strewn before them every day- I have dined with them myself, and that you shall do in time, too; for tell me what company you keep and I'll tell you who you are- up at the Hall they have two birds with green necks and a crest upon their heads; they can spread out their tails like a great wheel, and these are so bright with various colours that it makes one's eyes ache.

author: HCAndersen
text: These birds are called peacocks, and that is 'the beautiful.'

author: HCAndersen
text: If they were only plucked a little they would look no better than the rest of us.

author: HCAndersen
text: I would have plucked them already if they had not been so big."

author: HCAndersen
text: "I'll pluck them," piped the young sparrow, who had no feathers yet.

author: HCAndersen
text: In the farmhouse lived a young married couple; they loved each other dearly, were industrious and active, and everything in their home looked very nice.

author: HCAndersen
text: On Sundays the young wife came down early, plucked a handful of the most beautiful roses, and put them into a glass of water, which she placed upon the cupboard.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Now I see that it is Sunday," said the husband, kissing his little wife.

author: HCAndersen
text: They sat down, read their hymn-book, and held each other by the hand, while the sun shone down upon the fresh roses and upon them.

author: HCAndersen
text: "This sight is really too tedious," said the sparrow-mother, who could see into the room from her nest; and she flew away.

author: HCAndersen
text: The same thing happened on the following Sunday, for every Sunday fresh roses were put into the glass; but the rose-bush bloomed as beautifully as ever.

author: HCAndersen
text: The young sparrows now had feathers, and wanted very much to fly with their mother; but she would not allow it, and so they had to stay at home.

author: HCAndersen
text: In one of her flights, however it may have happened, she was caught, before she was aware of it, in a horse-hair net which some boys had attached to a tree.

author: HCAndersen
text: The horse-hair was drawn tightly round her leg- as tightly as if the latter were to be cut off; she was in great pain and terror.

author: HCAndersen
text: The boys came running up and seized her, and in no gentle way either.

author: HCAndersen
text: "It's only a sparrow," they said; they did not, however, let her go, but took her home with them, and every time she cried they hit her on the beak.

author: HCAndersen
text: In the farmhouse was an old man who understood making soap into cakes and balls, both for shaving and washing.

author: HCAndersen
text: He was a merry old man, always wandering about.

author: HCAndersen
text: On seeing the sparrow which the boys had brought, and which they said they did not want, he asked, "Shall we make it look very pretty?"

author: HCAndersen
text: At these words an icy shudder ran through the sparrow-mother.

author: HCAndersen
text: Out of his box, in which were the most beautiful colours, the old man took a quantity of shining leaf-gold, while the boys had to go and fetch some white of egg, with which the sparrow was to be smeared all over; the gold was stuck on to this, and the sparrow-mother was now gilded all over.

author: HCAndersen
text: But she, trembling in every limb, did not think of the adornment.

author: HCAndersen
text: Then the soap-man tore off a small piece from the red lining of his old jacket, and cutting it so as to make it look like a cock's comb, he stuck it to the bird's head.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Now you will see the gold-jacket fly," said the old man, letting the sparrow go, which flew away in deadly fear, with the sun shining upon her.

author: HCAndersen
text: How she glittered!

author: HCAndersen
text: All the sparrows, and even a crow- and an old boy he was too- were startled at the sight; but still they flew after her to learn what kind of strange bird she was.

author: HCAndersen
text: Driven by fear and horror, she flew homeward; she was almost sinking fainting to the earth, while the flock of pursuing birds increased, some even attempting to peck at her.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Look at her!

author: HCAndersen
text: Look at her!" they all cried.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Look at her!

author: HCAndersen
text: Look at her" cried her little ones. as she approached the nest.

author: HCAndersen
text: "That is certainly a young peacock, for it glitters in all colours; it makes one's eyes ache, as mother told us.

author: HCAndersen
text: Peep! that's 'the beautiful'."

author: HCAndersen
text: And then they pecked at the bird with their little beaks so that it was impossible for her to get into the nest; she was so exhausted that she couldn't even say "Peep!" much less "I am your own mother!"

author: HCAndersen
text: The other birds, too, now fell upon the sparrow and plucked off feather after feather until she fell bleeding into the rose-bush.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Poor creature!" said all the roses; "only be still, and we will hide you.

author: HCAndersen
text: Lean your little head against us.

author: HCAndersen
text: The sparrow spread out her wings once more, then drew them closely to her, and lay dead near the neighbouring family, the beautiful fresh roses.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Peep!" sounded from the nest.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Where can mother be so long?

author: HCAndersen
text: It's more than I can understand.

author: HCAndersen
text: It cannot be a trick of hers, and mean that we are now to take care of ourselves.

author: HCAndersen
text: She has left us the house as an inheritance; but to which of us is it to belong when we have families of our own?"

author: HCAndersen
text: "Yes, it won't do for you to stay with me when I increase my household with a wife and children,"' said the smallest.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I daresay I shall have more wives and children than you," said the second.

author: HCAndersen
text: "But I am the eldest!" exclaimed the third.

author: HCAndersen
text: Then they all got excited; they hit out with their wings, pecked with their beaks, and flop! one after another was thrown out of the nest.

author: HCAndersen
text: There they lay with their anger, holding their heads on one side and blinking the eye that was turned upwards.

author: HCAndersen
text: That was their way of looking foolish.

author: HCAndersen
text: They could fly a little; by practice they learned to improve, and at last they agreed upon a sign by which to recognise each other if they should meet in the world later on.

author: HCAndersen
text: It was to be one "Peep!" and three scratches on the ground with the left foot.

author: HCAndersen
text: The young one who had remained behind in the nest made himself as broad as he could, for he was the proprietor.

author: HCAndersen
text: But this greatness did not last long.

author: HCAndersen
text: In the night the red flames burst through the window and seized the roof, the dry straw blazed up high, and the whole house, together with the young sparrow, was burned.

author: HCAndersen
text: The two others, who wanted to marry, thus saved their lives by a stroke of luck.

author: HCAndersen
text: When the sun rose again and everything looked as refreshed as if it had had a quiet sleep, there only remained of the farmhouse a few black charred beams leaning against the chimney, which was now its own master.

author: HCAndersen
text: Thick smoke still rose from the ruins, but the rose-bush stood yonder, fresh, blooming, and untouched, every flower and every twig being reflected in the clear water.

author: HCAndersen
text: "How beautifully the roses bloom before the ruined house," exclaimed a passer-by.

author: HCAndersen
text: "A pleasanter picture cannot be imagined.

author: HCAndersen
text: I must have that."

author: HCAndersen
text: And the man took out of his portfolio a little book with white leaves: he was a painter, and with his pencil he drew the smoking house, the charred beams and the overhanging chimney, which bent more and more; in the foreground he put the large, blooming rose-bush, which presented a charming view.

author: HCAndersen
text: For its sake alone the whole picture had been drawn.

author: HCAndersen
text: Later in the day the two sparrows who had been born there came by.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Where is the house?" they asked.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Where is the nest?

author: HCAndersen
text: Peep!

author: HCAndersen
text: All is burned and our strong brother too.

author: HCAndersen
text: That's what he has now for keeping the nest.

author: HCAndersen
text: The roses got off very well; there they still stand with their red cheeks.

author: HCAndersen
text: They certainly do not mourn at their neighbours' misfortunes.

author: HCAndersen
text: I don't want to talk to them, and it looks miserable here- that's my opinion."

author: HCAndersen
text: And away they went.

author: HCAndersen
text: On a beautiful sunny autumn day- one could almost have believed it was still the middle of summer- there hopped about in the dry clean-swept courtyard before the principal entrance of the Hall a number of black, white, and gaily-coloured pigeons, all shining in the sunlight.

author: HCAndersen
text: The pigeon-mothers said to their young ones: "Stand in groups, stand in groups! for that looks much better."

author: HCAndersen
text: "What kind of creatures are those little grey ones that run about behind us?" asked an old pigeon, with red and green in her eyes.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Little grey ones!

author: HCAndersen
text: Little grey ones!" she cried.

author: HCAndersen
text: "They are sparrows, and good creatures.

author: HCAndersen
text: We have always had the reputation of being pious, so we will allow them to pick up the corn with us; they don't interrupt our talk, and they scrape so prettily when they bow."

author: HCAndersen
text: Indeed they were continually making three foot-scrapings with the left foot and also said "Peep!"

author: HCAndersen
text: By this means they recognised each other, for they were the sparrows from the nest on the burned house.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Here is excellent fare!" said the sparrow.

author: HCAndersen
text: The pigeons strutted round one another, puffed out their chests mightily, and had their own private views and opinions.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Do you see that pouter pigeon?" said one to the other.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Do you see how she swallows the peas?

author: HCAndersen
text: She eats too many, and the best ones too.

author: HCAndersen
text: Curoo!

author: HCAndersen
text: Curoo!

author: HCAndersen
text: How she lifts her crest, the ugly, spiteful creature!

author: HCAndersen
text: Curoo!

author: HCAndersen
text: Curoo!"

author: HCAndersen
text: And the eyes of all sparkled with malice.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Stand in groups!

author: HCAndersen
text: Stand in groups!

author: HCAndersen
text: Little grey ones, little grey ones!

author: HCAndersen
text: Curoo, curoo, curoo!"

author: HCAndersen
text: So their chatter ran on, and so it will run on for thousands of years.

author: HCAndersen
text: The sparrows ate lustily; they listened attentively, and even stood in the ranks with the others, but it did not suit them at all.

author: HCAndersen
text: They were full, and so they left the pigeons, exchanging opinions about them, slipped in under the garden palings, and when they found the door leading into the house open, one of them, who was more than full, and therefore felt brave, hopped on to the threshold.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Peep!" said he; "I may venture that."

author: HCAndersen
text: "Peep!" said the other; "so may I, and something more too!" and he hopped into the room.

author: HCAndersen
text: No one was there; the third sparrow, seeing this, flew still farther into the room, exclaiming, "All or nothing!

author: HCAndersen
text: It is a curious man's nest all the same; and what have they put up here?

author: HCAndersen
text: What is it?"

author: HCAndersen
text: Close to the sparrows the roses were blooming; they were reflected in the water, and the charred beams leaned against the overhanging chimney.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Do tell me what this is.

author: HCAndersen
text: How comes this in a room at the Hall?"

author: HCAndersen
text: And all three sparrows wanted to fly over the roses and the chimney, but flew against a flat wall.

author: HCAndersen
text: It was all a picture, a great splendid picture, which the artist had painted from a sketch.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Peep!" said the sparrows, "it's nothing.

author: HCAndersen

author: HCAndersen

author: HCAndersen

author: HCAndersen

author: HCAndersen
text: And they flew away, for some people came into the room.

author: HCAndersen
text: Days and years went by.

author: HCAndersen
text: The pigeons had often cooed, not to say growled- the spiteful creatures; the sparrows had been frozen in winter and had lived merrily in summer: they were all betrothed, or married, or whatever you like to call it.

author: HCAndersen
text: They had little ones, and of course each one thought his own the handsomest and cleverest; one flew this way, another that, and when they met they recognised each other by their "Peep!" and the three scrapes with the left foot.

author: HCAndersen
text: The eldest had remained an old maid and had no nest nor young ones.

author: HCAndersen
text: It was her pet idea to see a great city, so she flew to Copenhagen.

author: HCAndersen
text: There was a large house painted in many gay colours standing close to the castle and the canal, upon which latter were to be seen many ships laden with apples and pottery.

author: HCAndersen
text: The windows of the house were broader at the bottom than at the top, and when the sparrows looked through them, every room appeared to them like a tulip with the brightest colours and shades.

author: HCAndersen
text: But in the middle of the tulip stood white men, made of marble; a few were of plaster; still, looked at with sparrows' eyes, that comes to the same thing.

author: HCAndersen
text: Up on the roof stood a metal chariot drawn by metal horses, and the goddess of Victory, also of metal, was driving.

author: HCAndersen
text: It was Thorwaldsen's Museum.

author: HCAndersen
text: "How it shines! how it shines!" said the maiden sparrow.

author: HCAndersen
text: "I suppose that is 'the beautiful.'

author: HCAndersen
text: Peep!

author: HCAndersen

author: HCAndersen
text: She still remembered what in her childhood's days her mother had looked upon as the greatest among the beautiful.

author: HCAndersen
text: She flew down into the courtyard: there everything was extremely fine.

author: HCAndersen
text: Palms and branches were painted on the walls, and in the middle of the court stood a great blooming rose-tree spreading out its fresh boughs, covered with roses, over a grave.

author: HCAndersen
text: Thither flew the maiden sparrow, for she saw several of her own kind there.

author: HCAndersen
text: A "peep" and three foot-scrapings- in this way she had often greeted throughout the year, and no one here had responded, for those who are once parted do not meet every day; and so this greeting had become a habit with her.

author: HCAndersen
text: But to-day two old sparrows and a young one answered with a "peep" and the thrice-repeated scrape with the left foot.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Ah!

author: HCAndersen
text: Good-day! good-day!"

author: HCAndersen

author: HCAndersen

author: HCAndersen
text: It's a grand place, but there's not much to eat.

author: HCAndersen

author: HCAndersen

author: HCAndersen
text: Many people came out of the side rooms where the beautiful marble statues stood and approached the grave where lay the great master who had created these works of art.

author: HCAndersen
text: All stood with enraptured faces round Thorwaldsen's grave, and a few picked up the fallen rose-leaves and preserved them.

author: HCAndersen
text: They had come from afar: one from mighty England, others from Germany and France.

author: HCAndersen
text: The fairest of the ladies plucked one of the roses and hid it in her bosom.

author: HCAndersen
text: Then the sparrows thought that the roses reigned here, and that the house had been built for their sake.

author: HCAndersen
text: That appeared to them to be really too much, but since all the people showed their love for the roses, they did not wish to be behindhand.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Peep!" they said sweeping the ground with their tails, and blinking with one eye at the roses, they had not looked at them long before they were convinced that they were their old neighbours.

author: HCAndersen
text: And so they really were.

author: HCAndersen
text: The painter who had drawn the rose-bush near the ruined house, had afterwards obtained permission to dig it up, and had given it to the architect, for finer roses had never been seen.

author: HCAndersen
text: The architect had planted it upon Thorwaldsen's grave, where it bloomed as an emblem of 'the beautiful' and yielded fragrant red rose-leaves to be carried as mementoes to distant lands.

author: HCAndersen
text: "Have you obtained an appointment here in the city?" asked the sparrows.

author: HCAndersen
text: The roses nodded; they recognized their grey neighbours and were pleased to see them again.

author: HCAndersen
text: "How glorious it is to live and to bloom, to see old friends again, and happy faces every day.

author: HCAndersen

author: HCAndersen

author: HCAndersen
text: But the tree stood there fresher and greener than ever; the roses bloomed in the sunshine on Thorwaldsen's grave and became associated with his immortal name.
